creator: bayern@essentially.net
text:
sendRedirect() uses toAbsolute() to convert relative to absolute URLs; this
latter method determines whether a MalformedURLException was thrown when
deciding whether a URL is absolute or relative.  While this logic might be
appropriate in some cases, it does not seem appropriate for sendRedirect(),
which a developer should (as far as I can tell) legally be able to use to
redirect a user's browser to a URL not understood by the servlet container.
That is, there should be no requirement that the container accept the URL
as valid; the decision is up to the browser.

An example where the behavior is pragmatically undesirable is redirection to an
"https" URL by a container whose Java installation does not recognize HTTPS URLs
as valid (even despite the presence of JSSE -- i.e., without the appropriate
system property set).

sendRedirect() should (arguably) use explicit string-processing logic to
determine relative vs. absolute URLs instead of relying on the occurrence of a
MalformedURLException (in a situation where this is not truly exceptional).

You're correct, of course.  Do I get points for trying to be constructively
lazy?  :-)

Will be fixed soon.
